Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exploring the relative importance of biotic and environmental sources of selection for pine-fungal interactions

Research that considers mechanisms by which plants evolve in response to complex environments including mutualists, enemies, and variable environmental factors is important for understanding what the most important selective factors are in driving trait evolution in plants. Interactions among plant hosts and their diverse associated microbes may provide an ecologically unique arena in which to examine the nature of selection in multispecies interactions. In particular, interactions between coniferous plants and their associated microbes provide a good system for experiments exploring the relative importance of sources of selection, as conifers interact with a suite of belowground microorganisms, and these interactions vary along environmental gradients. Using experimental approaches, this research will investigate the evolutionary dynamics of traits surrounding the interaction among plants, enemies and mutualists under changing environmental conditions. Novel field estimates of selection will be conducted and key predictions of coevolutionary theory will be tested.

Training objectives include developing expertise in statistical, empirical and analytical techniques. Career enhancement activities comprise the development of a unique research program including developing skills related to publication and presentation of research. The broader impacts of this project include training for underrepresented undergraduates in research skills such as field collection, molecular work, statistics and scientific presentation. Finally, while Monterey pine is considered threatened in its native range, it is widely cultivated as a plantation timber species in many temperate parts of the world so research which considers its response to changes in biotic and abiotic selection forces will inform both conservation and agricultural practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Megan Rúa has completed her tenure as a NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology. During her funding period she spent three years as a member of the Hoeksema Lab at the University of Mississippi in Oxford, MS. As a microbial evolutionary ecologist her interests focus on utilizing methods and theories from community ecology and evolution for understanding plants and their microbes. This is particularly important as new, cheaper technology allows scientists to identify more and more microbes, many of whom have unknown functions and ecological histories.

The research pursued as part of this project investigated the potential role of plant genetic background in shaping the co-evolutionary relationship between plants, their microbes, and the environment. (i.e., how these three integral components of terrestrial ecosystems have shaped each other). In order to do this Dr. Rúa planted two common gardens, each with 2200 plants from many genotypes of the same host species (Monterey pine, Pinus radiata). After five months the surviving seedlings were harvested and the belowground fungal community was identified. This has produced an incredibly extensive dataset. Using an analysis technique originally applied to plants and their pollinators, Dr. Rúa has begun to estimate natural selection as well as attribute the source of this selection to either the environment or other fungi. This analysis is incredibly complex so in order to fully complete this analysis, Dr. Rúa is pursuing an additional year of postdoctoral research at the National Institute for Mathematical and Biological Synthesis (2015-2016).

In addition to her scientific research, Dr. Rúa has served as a mentor for seven undergraduates (five female and two male), including two University of Mississippi Honors Fellows. These students have been active participants in all avenues of research, from field work, to basic laboratory work to intensive molecular work. Work from two of these students, an honors thesis and a research project, have already been published (Rúa, M.A., Moore, B., Hergott, N.,  Van, L., Jackson, C.R.,  Hoeksema. J.D. In press. Ectomycorrhizal fungal communities and enzymatic activities vary across an ecotone between a forest and field. Journal of Fungi). These research and mentoring opportunities have influenced the career trajectories of these students greatly: two students are now attending pharmacy school, two attending medical school, one working in a laboratory at Harvard University, one attending graduate school for public health, and a student still finishing his undergraduate degree.

Finally, as a postdoctoral fellowship one of the goals of the NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship Program in Biology is to prepare recipients for tenure track positions. To this end, during her tenure as a NSF Postdoctoral Fellows in Biology, Dr. Rúa interviewed at several institutions throughout the US and has chosen to accept a tenure track position at Wright State University to begin Fall 2016.
